intro: Amomum quadratolaminare, commonly known as the broad-leafed cardamom, is a perennial herb native to Southeast Asia. It belongs to the ginger family, Zingiberaceae, and is characterized by its aromatic, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, pale green flowers that are followed by triangular, three-lobed fruits. Its rhizomes are used in traditional medicine and as a spice due to their distinctive fragrance and flavor. The botanical features of A. quadratolaminare make it an important species in both horticulture and culinary applications.
